config.task_description: Create a 5-page comic script based on 'The Baghdad Divergence' alternate history. Page 1: The surrender of Baghdad in 1258 and the preservation of the House of Wisdom. Page 2: The flourishing of the Mongol-Abbasid 'Super-State' and the survival of the 'Shadow Library'. Page 3: The stagnation of feudal Europe, spared from the Black Death but trapped in a Malthusian cycle without a Renaissance. Page 4: The Pacific-centric discovery of the Americas by Malay and Persian navigators. Page 5: The modern era of Afro-Eurasian hegemony and the rise of authoritarian Western megastates.
config.style_details: A blend of traditional Islamic and Mongol aesthetics with advanced technology (Silkpunk) for the East, featuring rich colors and intricate geometric patterns. Contrast this with a grim, brutalist, and feudal 'Gothic Industrial' look for the Western megastates, using muted and cold tones. Visuals should emphasize the scale of the Afro-Eurasian cities and the oppressive nature of the Western bureaucracies.

script.title: The Baghdad Divergence
script.premise: In 1258, Baghdad does not fall to the Mongol sword; it surrenders to the Mongol mind. This single act of pragmatism preserves the Islamic Golden Age, leading to a world where the East achieves a Silkpunk technological revolution while the West remains trapped in a feudal, Malthusian nightmare, eventually emerging as a brutalist, authoritarian megastate.

characters.name: Al-Jazari II (The Chronicler)
characters.description: A high-ranking scholar-engineer of the House of Wisdom in the "present" (19th-century equivalent). Calm, intellectual, and authoritative.
characters.visual_traits: Wears flowing robes of smart-silk with integrated brass circuitry. He has a mechanical prosthetic eye designed like an astrolabe.

characters.name: Hulagu Khan (The Preserver)
characters.description: The Mongol commander who accepted Baghdad’s surrender. He is depicted in flashbacks as a visionary rather than a destroyer.
characters.visual_traits: Traditional Mongol armor but adorned with Persian calligraphy.

characters.name: Klaus 704 (The Western Proletariat)
characters.description: A citizen of the "Atlantic Megastate" (the Western Super-USSR). Represents the "Gothic Industrial" aesthetic.
characters.visual_traits: Gaunt, wearing a heavy, soot-stained industrial uniform. Shaved head with a barcode tattoo on the neck.

frames.description: A wide shot of Baghdad, 1258. The Mongol army surrounds the city, but the gates are open. White flags fly alongside the Abbasid black.
Close up of Hulagu Khan and the Caliph Al-Musta'sim. Instead of a sword, Hulagu holds a scroll.
frames.caption: History is a narrative skin stretched over the skeleton of power. In your world, Baghdad burned. In ours, it breathed.

frames.description: Scholars carrying crates of books *into* the Mongol camp, protected by Mongol warriors.

dialog.text: Your ink is more valuable than your blood, Caliph. We shall build a heaven of logic together.

rows.visual_description: The Surrender: A sequence showing the peaceful surrender of Baghdad to the Mongols.

frames.description: Inside the House of Wisdom. It is bustling. Mongol administrators and Arab scholars work side-by-side.
A montage of scientific diagrams: Alhazen’s optics evolving into complex lens systems; early calculus notations on parchment.
frames.caption: The human chain of transmission remained unbroken. The "Shadow Library" was never lost to the flames.

rows.visual_description: The Shadow Library: Depicting the preservation of knowledge and collaboration between Mongols and Arabs.

frames.description: A map of Eurasia. The Mongol Empire and the Caliphate merge into a single, vibrant gold entity.
A Silkpunk city skyline. Minarets topped with brass lightning rods; gliders with silk wings soaring between towers.

dialog.text: Power preceded the idea. Because the center held, the mind soared.

rows.visual_description: The Super-Abbasid State: Showing the geopolitical merger and the resulting Silkpunk technology.

frames.description: A bustling, filthy medieval London. It is overcrowded. People are packed into narrow streets.
A merchant ship in the Black Sea turning away from a Mongol port.
frames.caption: In the East, stability. In the West, stagnation. The trade routes shifted south. The Black Death never reached the Atlantic shores.

frames.description: A feudal lord on a horse, lashing a peasant. The peasant looks malnourished and broken.

rows.visual_description: The Missing Plague: Depicting the stagnation and overcrowding of the West.

frames.description: A massive stone cathedral under construction, but the technology looks primitive—wooden pulleys and thousands of straining slaves.
A close-up of a "Knight-Inquisitor" in heavy, rusted plate armor, looking through a slit at a crowd of starving serfs.
frames.caption: Without the labor shortage of the plague, the peasant remained a slave. The Renaissance was strangled in its crib.

rows.visual_description: The Feudal Lock: Showing the lack of technological progress and oppression in Europe.

frames.description: A scholar in a dark cell, hiding a forbidden Greek text. He looks terrified.
A bonfire of books in a village square, lit by a priest.
frames.caption: Europe remained a Malthusian trap. A world of high-tech empires in the East, and low-tech subjects in the West.

rows.visual_description: The Dark Ages Prolonged: Illustrating the suppression of knowledge in the West.

frames.description: A massive Afro-Eurasian fleet—ships with multiple masts and lateen sails, reinforced with iron bands—sailing across a calm Pacific.
A navigator using a complex, clockwork astrolabe to chart the stars.
frames.caption: While the Atlantic remained a wall for the backward West, the Pacific became our lake.

rows.visual_description: The Eastward Discovery: The Eastern fleet sailing the Pacific with advanced navigation.

frames.description: The fleet arrives at a lush coastline (California). Indigenous people (Ohlone/Miwok) approach the shore, but they are met with traders, not conquistadors.
A hybrid city: Incan stonework merged with Persian arches and Mongol yurts.

dialog.text: We did not come to displace. We came to integrate. The Americas became civilizational satellites.

rows.visual_description: The New World Encounter: Peaceful integration and hybrid architecture in the Americas.

frames.description: A marketplace in this new world. Jade, spices, and silver being traded for Baghdad-made clockwork and silk.
A young Indigenous girl wearing a silk scarf, looking at a mechanical bird.
frames.caption: Smallpox arrived as a whisper, not a scream. Immunity grew through commerce, not conquest.

rows.visual_description: The Global Trade: Commerce and cultural exchange in the New World.

frames.description: A massive explosion in a European city. The feudal order is being torn down by a desperate, starving populace.
A new leader emerges on a balcony—a "Techno-Autocrat" in a sharp, militaristic uniform.
frames.caption: The "Rich Idiots" of the West pushed extraction too far. The explosion was inevitable.

rows.visual_description: The Rupture: The violent overthrow of the feudal order in the West.

frames.description: A sprawling, concrete megacity stretching across the European plain. Smoke stacks choke the sky.
Klaus 704 stands in a massive assembly line, his movements synchronized with a thousand others.

dialog.text: The State is the only God. The State is the only bread. We must catch up to the Golden East.

rows.visual_description: The Super-USSR Aesthetic: The grim, industrial reality of the Western Megastate.

frames.description: A propaganda poster in the West: A giant fist crushing a crown, with the slogan "UNITY THROUGH ORDER."
A Western "Land-Dreadnought"—a massive, coal-belching tank—patrolling a border wall.
frames.caption: They did not build nations. They built a Megastate. A hyper-centralized machine designed for one purpose: survival against the Hegemony.

rows.visual_description: Vertical Identity: Propaganda and militarization of the West.

frames.description: Left: A Baghdad cafe. People of all ethnicities debate philosophy under a canopy of bioluminescent plants.
Right: A Western ration station. Grey-clad citizens stand in line for synthetic paste under the watchful eye of turret-drones.

dialog.text: Two paths. One born of preservation, the other of catastrophe.

rows.visual_description: The Contrast: Split-screen comparing the elegant East and the brutal West.

frames.description: A high-altitude view of the border between the Hegemony and the Megastate (the Urals).
A ritualized skirmish: Elegant, solar-powered Hegemony drones intercepting a swarm of crude, chemical-fueled Western missiles.
frames.caption: War is no longer an existential struggle. It is a ritual of prestige between civilizational blocs.

rows.visual_description: The Grammar of War: High-tech Eastern drones vs. crude Western missiles.

frames.description: Al-Jazari II looks out from a balcony in Baghdad. The city is a jewel of light and geometry.
Close up on his mechanical eye, reflecting the stars.

dialog.text: The 'Rise of the West' was never a destiny. It was a tragedy that didn't have to happen.

frames.description: A wide shot of the Earth from space. The Eastern hemisphere is a glowing web of golden light; the Western hemisphere is a dark, bruised purple.
frames.caption: The map flipped. And the light stayed on.

rows.visual_description: The Final Reflection: Al-Jazari II reflecting on the world, ending with a view from space.
